s.text: But the more interesting aspect of Rudy Giuliani's latest attempt to bring order to our fair city was the way it showcased how little parking there is in New York.
And it's certainly true that most double-parkers are just people trying to avoid paying for a parking garage, or deliverymen trying to avoid having to walk around the corner.

But in a deeper sense, the limits on garages are emblematic of the way successive administrations in New York have handled most things: They have consistently assumed that without a strong managerial hand, the city would degenerate into chaos.

But in a deeper sense, the limits on garages are emblematic of the way successive administrations in New York have handled most things: They have consistently assumed that without a strong managerial hand, the city would degenerate into chaos.
Because obtaining a taxi medallion is next to impossible, and the price of the medallions has soared out of sight.
(In some sense, it probably was, and in Moneybox tomorrow, I'll have something on whether this matters.)
In that sense, the implicit governing philosophy in New York has been "avoid the tragedy of the commons" (while also letting the people on the inside wet their beaks over and over again).
Pace a recent Chatterbox piece, New York is certainly an exception to his rule about cheap movie tickets, and one reason is that there are too few movie theaters here to meet the demand.
Parking real estate is not quite as valuable as land in the Hamptons, but it has a similar characteristic: The supply isn't getting any bigger, even as the demand grows.
And, in any case, parking garages are usually full.
But the more interesting aspect of Rudy Giuliani's latest attempt to bring order to our fair city was the way it showcased how little parking there is in New York.
